lines.text: Enter BAPTISTA, VINCENTIO, GREMIO, the Pedant,  LUCENTIO, BIANCA, PETRUCHIO, KATHARINA, HORTENSIO,  and Widow, TRANIO, BIONDELLO, and GRUMIO the Serving-men with Tranio bringing in a banquet

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: At last, though long, our jarring notes agree: And time it is, when raging war is done, To smile at scapes and perils overblown. My fair Bianca, bid my father welcome, While I with self-same kindness welcome thine. Brother Petruchio, sister Katharina, And thou, Hortensio, with thy loving widow, Feast with the best, and welcome to my house: My banquet is to close our stomachs up, After our great good cheer. Pray you, sit down; For now we sit to chat as well as eat.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Nothing but sit and sit, and eat and eat!

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Padua affords this kindness, son Petruchio.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Padua affords nothing but what is kind.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: For both our sakes, I would that word were true.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Now, for my life, Hortensio fears his widow.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Then never trust me, if I be afeard.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: He that is giddy thinks the world turns round.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Roundly replied.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Mistress, how mean you that?

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Thus I conceive by him.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: My widow says, thus she conceives her tale.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Very well mended. Kiss him for that, good widow.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: 'He that is giddy thinks the world turns round:' I pray you, tell me what you meant by that.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Your husband, being troubled with a shrew, Measures my husband's sorrow by his woe: And now you know my meaning,

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: A very mean meaning.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Right, I mean you.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: And I am mean indeed, respecting you.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: To her, Kate!

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: To her, widow!

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A hundred marks, my Kate does put her down.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: That's my office.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Spoke like an officer; ha' to thee, lad!
Drinks to HORTENSIO

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Believe me, sir, they butt together well.

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Head, and butt! an hasty-witted body Would say your head and butt were head and horn.

lines.speaker: vincentio
lines.text: Ay, mistress bride, hath that awaken'd you?

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Ay, but not frighted me; therefore I'll sleep again.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Nay, that you shall not: since you have begun, Have at you for a bitter jest or two!

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Am I your bird? I mean to shift my bush; And then pursue me as you draw your bow. You are welcome all.
Exeunt BIANCA, KATHARINA, and Widow

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: She hath prevented me. Here, Signior Tranio. This bird you aim'd at, though you hit her not; Therefore a health to all that shot and miss'd.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: O, sir, Lucentio slipp'd me like his greyhound, Which runs himself and catches for his master.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A good swift simile, but something currish.

lines.speaker: tranio
lines.text: 'Tis well, sir, that you hunted for yourself: 'Tis thought your deer does hold you at a bay.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: O ho, Petruchio! Tranio hits you now.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A' has a little gall'd me, I confess; And, as the jest did glance away from me, 'Tis ten to one it maim'd you two outright.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Now, in good sadness, son Petruchio, I think thou hast the veriest shrew of all.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Well, I say no: and therefore for assurance Let's each one send unto his wife; And he whose wife is most obedient To come at first when he doth send for her, Shall win the wager which we will propose.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Content. What is the wager?

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: Twenty crowns.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Twenty crowns! I'll venture so much of my hawk or hound, But twenty times so much upon my wife.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: A hundred then.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Content.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: A match! 'tis done.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Who shall begin?

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: That will I. Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.

lines.speaker: biondello
lines.text: I go.
Exit

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Son, I'll be your half, Bianca comes.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: I'll have no halves; I'll bear it all myself. How now! what news?
Re-enter BIONDELLO

lines.speaker: biondello
lines.text: Sir, my mistress sends you word That she is busy and she cannot come.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: How! she is busy and she cannot come! Is that an answer?

lines.speaker: gremio
lines.text: Ay, and a kind one too: Pray God, sir, your wife send you not a worse.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: I hope better.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Sirrah Biondello, go and entreat my wife To come to me forthwith.
Exit BIONDELLO

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: O, ho! entreat her! Nay, then she must needs come.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: I am afraid, sir, Do what you can, yours will not be entreated. Now, where's my wife?
Re-enter BIONDELLO

lines.speaker: biondello
lines.text: She says you have some goodly jest in hand: She will not come: she bids you come to her.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Worse and worse; she will not come! O vile, Intolerable, not to be endured! Sirrah Grumio, go to your mistress; Say, I command her to come to me.
Exit GRUMIO

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: I know her answer.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: She will not.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: The fouler fortune mine, and there an end.

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Now, by my holidame, here comes Katharina!
Re-enter KATARINA

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: What is your will, sir, that you send for me?

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Where is your sister, and Hortensio's wife?

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come. Swinge me them soundly forth unto their husbands: Away, I say, and bring them hither straight.
Exit KATHARINA

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: Here is a wonder, if you talk of a wonder.

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: And so it is: I wonder what it bodes.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Marry, peace it bodes, and love and quiet life, And awful rule and right supremacy; And, to be short, what not, that's sweet and happy?

lines.speaker: baptista
lines.text: Now, fair befal thee, good Petruchio! The wager thou hast won; and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns; Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed, as she had never been.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Nay, I will win my wager better yet And show more sign of her obedience, Her new-built virtue and obedience. See where she comes and brings your froward wives As prisoners to her womanly persuasion. Katharina, that cap of yours becomes you not: Off with that bauble, throw it under-foot.
Re-enter KATHARINA, with BIANCA and Widow

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Lord, let me never have a cause to sigh, Till I be brought to such a silly pass!

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: I would your duty were as foolish too: The wisdom of your duty, fair Bianca, Hath cost me an hundred crowns since supper-time.

lines.speaker: bianca
lines.text: The more fool you, for laying on my duty.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Katharina, I charge thee, tell these headstrong women What duty they do owe their lords and husbands.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: Come, come, you're mocking: we will have no telling.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Come on, I say; and first begin with her.

lines.speaker: widow
lines.text: She shall not.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: I say she shall: and first begin with her.

lines.speaker: katharina
lines.text: Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow, And dart not scornful glances from those eyes, To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor: It blots thy beauty as frosts do bite the meads, Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds, And in no sense is meet or amiable. A woman moved is like a fountain troubled, Muddy, ill-seeming, thick, bereft of beauty; And while it is so, none so dry or thirsty Will deign to sip or touch one drop of it. Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper, Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee, And for thy maintenance commits his body To painful labour both by sea and land, To watch the night in storms, the day in cold, Whilst thou liest warm at home, secure and safe; And craves no other tribute at thy hands But love, fair looks and true obedience; Too little payment for so great a debt. Such duty as the subject owes the prince Even such a woman oweth to her husband; And when she is froward, peevish, sullen, sour, And not obedient to his honest will, What is she but a foul contending rebel And graceless traitor to her loving lord? I am ashamed that women are so simple To offer war where they should kneel for peace; Or seek for rule, supremacy and sway, When they are bound to serve, love and obey. Why are our bodies soft and weak and smooth, Unapt to toil and trouble in the world, But that our soft conditions and our hearts Should well agree with our external parts? Come, come, you froward and unable worms! My mind hath been as big as one of yours, My heart as great, my reason haply more, To bandy word for word and frown for frown; But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are. Then vail your stomachs, for it is no boot, And place your hands below your husband's foot: In token of which duty, if he please, My hand is ready; may it do him ease.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Why, there's a wench! Come on, and kiss me, Kate.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: Well, go thy ways, old lad; for thou shalt ha't.

lines.speaker: vincentio
lines.text: 'Tis a good hearing when children are toward.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: But a harsh hearing when women are froward.

lines.speaker: petruchio
lines.text: Come, Kate, we'll to bed. We three are married, but you two are sped. 'Twas I won the wager, though you hit the white; And, being a winner, God give you good night!
To LUCENTIO
Exeunt PETRUCHIO and KATHARINA

lines.speaker: hortensio
lines.text: Now, go thy ways; thou hast tamed a curst shrew.

lines.speaker: lucentio
lines.text: 'Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so. of thunder and lightning heard.
Exeunt
